election_record.label: Vermont 1812 U.S. House of Representatives

overview.note: The Official Results list Ezra Butler with 16009 votes, William Strong with 16004 votes, Charles Rich with 15997 votes, William C. Bradley with 15987 votes, Martin Chittenden with 15774 votes, Chauncey Langdon with 15758 votes, Daniel Chipman with 15750 votes, Jonathan Hubbard with 15750 votes, William Chamberlain with 15747 votes and John Noyes with 15732 votes but the county totals add up to 16010 votes for Butler, 15998 votes for Strong, 15995 votes for Rich, 15988 votes for Bradley, 15747 votes for Chittenden, 15731 votes for Langdon, 15723 votes for Chipman, 15722 votes for Hubbard, 15720 votes for Chamberlain and 15705 votes for Noyes.

The Green-Mountain Farmer (Bennington, VT), January 5, 1813, The Rutland Vermont Herald (Rutland, VT), January 6, 1813, The National Intelligencer (Washington, DC), January 18, 1813, The Alexandria Herald (Alexandria, VA), January 20, 1813, and The Republican Star (Easton MD), February 2, 1813, report 16026 votes for Richard Skinner, 16005 votes for Ezra Butler, 15993 votes for Charles Rich, 15976 votes for William Strong, 15919 votes for William C. Bradley, 15774 votes for Martin Chittenden, 15758 votes for Chauncey Langdon, 15751 votes for Daniel Chipman, 15476 votes for Jonathan H. Hubbard, 15740 votes for William Chamberlain and 15731 votes for John Noyes.

The Vermont Mirror (Middlebury, VT), January 6, 1813, reports 16660 votes for Richard Skinner, 16015 votes for Ezra Butler, 15993 votes for Charles Rich, 15976 votes for William Strong, 15922 votes for William C. Bradley, 15774 votes for Martin Chittenden, 15758 votes for Chauncey Langdon, 15751 votes for Daniel Chipman, 15526 votes for Jonathan H. Hubbard, 15740 votes for William Chamberlain and 15731 votes for John Noyes.

Bennington News-Letter (Bennington, VT), January 6, 1813, and The Rutland Vermont Herald (Rutland, VT), January 6, 1813, reports 16026 votes for Richard Skinner, 16005 votes for Ezra Butler, 15993 votes for Charles Rich, 15976 votes for William Strong, 15919 votes for William C. Bradley, 15774 votes for Martin Chittenden, 15758 votes for Chauncey Langdon, 15651 votes for Daniel Chipman, 15476 votes for Jonathan H. Hubbard, 15740 votes for William Chamberlain and 15731 votes for John Noyes.
The Green-Mountain Farmer (Bennington, VT), January 5, 1813, and The Rutland Vermont Herald (Rutland, VT), January 6, 1813, refer to the Federalist ticket as the Submission Ticket.
Bennington News-Letter (Bennington, VT) refers to the Federalist ticket as the Peace Ticket and the Republican ticket as the War Ticket.
The Vermont Mirror (Middlebury, VT), January 6, 1813: "The candidates elected are all Madisonian Democrats."

The Green-Mountain Farmer (Bennington, VT), January 5, 1813: "From the above statement it appears, that the Federal Ticket has received about 200 only and the Republican Ticket 3150 less, than their respective votes for governor, in September last. 3150 Fail us for a Day, yet Heaven preserves Republican Rights, against a host of foes, marshaled and pitted to a single man, in the small state of Vermont. Our satisfaction will be much more easily conceived by congenial minds, than we can express by language, on finding that ALL THE VOTES given in by the freemen of this state, for representatives to Congress were counted: NOT A VOTE WAS OMITTED IN THE CANVASING: This we are fully authorised to assert, the cavils of coalition opponents notwithstanding. The Boston Centinel affirmed the election of SIX SUBMISSION MEN from VERMONT to mis-represent her in the next Congress: the evil is averted, our representation is consonant to our established political character: To roast a BUCK whole, claimed by a sportsman, tho' shot by another man, (as we hear had been promised in Bennington, to feast the Feds. and Clintonians,) would now be unnecessary, an Arlington RABBIT, if caught, would be sufficient to feast on surfeiting all of that description in Bennington, who will rejoice in the auspicious result. While the enemies of republicanism have been boasting of its decline in Vermont, and spreading the falacy of their success from east to west, and from north to south, including Nova Scotia and Canada, we have only stated that from the inattention of the republicans the result was not certain. In the event we find that the state retains her character ."

Bennington News-Letter (Bennington, VT), January 6, 1813: "The following has been handed to us, as the result of the late Congressional Election in this State: and although the war party, and the friends of the present ruinous measures, have prevailed, it is by a decreased majority, that must astonish every one. Had this election taken place ten days later, after the remains of the drafted militia, who had been forced to the lines last fall to do nothing, returned to their homes, it would have made an accession to the peace Ticket of 2000 votes. This the War-Hawks well knew, and therefore prudently prevented this sickly, abused and degraded corps, from returning in season to palm their opinions upon their friends and acquaintance before the election. Add to this, that many desponding of success, did not come to the polls, thinking from the late democratic majority, that all was lost. We hope this error in judgement will not again keep any friend to his country from elections."

The Rutland Vermont Herald (Rutland, VT), January 6, 1813: "We give the following schedule of Votes to shew the comparative result between the Fall and Congressional Election. Mr. Skinner and Mr. Chittenden, having the greatest number of votes on each Ticket for Members of Congress, we draw our comparison from the votes given to these two gentlemen with those given Gov. Galusha and Mr. Chittenden [in the election for Governor] ... From the foregoing and from other testimony on which much reliance may be placed, it is clear that the republican majority would have been nearly as large as last fall had there not been a criminal remisness on the part of the friends to government and honorable peace in attending the polls. It gives us pleasure that we are authorised to state, the votes of every town in the State were counted--not one lost--Capt. Dunham's suspicions to the contrary notwithstanding. It is worthy of remark that in the frontier Counties of Grand-Isle, Franklin, Orleans and Essex, which are most exposed to the consequent calamities resulting from war, there has been a nett gain in favor of the honorable peace over the combined Federal and Clintonian submission Ticket, which clearly shows that it is owing to the conscious security of the friends of union and honorable peace, in those towns that gave such overwhelming majorities last fall that the majority was so small at the late election. But we have reason to congratulate the citizens of Vermont who are friends to the union and honorable peace that in the thirteenth Congress Vermont will have but one voice--which has never been the case since she has been a member of the union."

sub_unit.name: Addison
sub_unit.note: The Official Results list Martin Chittenden with 1577 votes, Chauncey Langdon with 1574 votes, Daniel Chipman with 1577 votes, Jonathan Hubbard with 1576 votes, William Chamberlain with 1575 votes and John Noyes with 1574 votes but the town totals add up to 1550 votes for Chittenden, 1547 votes for Langdon, 1550 votes for Chipman, 1549 votes for Hubbard, 1548 votes for Chamberlain and 1547 votes for Noyes.

The Vermont Mirror (Middlebury, VT), January 6, 1813, reports 1469 votes for Richard Skinner, 1454 votes for William Strong, 1445 votes for William C. Bradley, 1577 votes for Martin Chittenden, 1574 votes for Chauncey Langdon, 1577 votes for Daniel Chipman, 1527 votes for Jonathan H. Hubbard, 1569 votes for William Chamberlain and 1574 votes for John Noyes.

sub_unit.name: Addison
sub_unit.note: One vote for Elijah Strong in Addison has been added to the total for William Strong.

sub_unit.name: Ferrisburgh
sub_unit.note: Eleven votes for John H. Hubbard and 31 votes for Jonathan Hubbard in Ferrisburgh have been added to the total for Jonathan H. Hubbard.
Six votes for William Hubbard in Ferrisburgh have been added to the total for William Chamberlain.

sub_unit.name: Middlebury
sub_unit.note: Six votes for William Hubbard in Middlebury have been added to the total for William Chamberlain.

sub_unit.name: Vergennes
sub_unit.note: These results are listed in the Original Election Returns as being for Vergennes and Waltham.

sub_unit.name: Weybridge
sub_unit.note: Twelve votes for William C. Crafts in Weybridge have been added to the total for William C. Bradley.

sub_unit.name: Bennington
sub_unit.note: The Vermont Mirror (Middlebury, VT), January 6, 1813, reports 1232 votes for William C. Bradley, and 981 votes for Jonathan H. Hubbard.

sub_unit.name: Bennington
sub_unit.note: Bennington News-Letter (Bennington, VT), December 9: "It is truly gratifying to the real Friend of Liberty, who has been led almost to 'despair of the Commonwealth,' to see the noble spirit which animated the freemen of this town, on the day of election, who, notwithstanding every art and intrigue had been put in requisiton to mislead and influence them. Yet unsolicited, they dared to come forward and act like Freemen: their votes are as follows ."

sub_unit.name: Sunderland
sub_unit.note: One vote for William H. Hubbard in Sunderland has been added to the total for Jonathan H. Hubbard.

sub_unit.name: Caledonia
sub_unit.note: The Official Results list Richard Skinner with 965 votes, Charles Rich with 966 votes and William C. Bradley with 965 votes but the town totals add up to 964 votes for Skinner, 965 votes for Rich and 964 votes for Bradley.
The Vermont Mirror (Middlebury, VT), January 6, 1813, reports 965 votes for Richard Skinner, 939 votes for William Strong, and 965 votes for William C. Bradley.

sub_unit.name: Lyndon
sub_unit.note: Fifty votes for John H. Hubbard in Lyndon have been added to the total for Jonathan H. Hubbard.

sub_unit.name: Waterford
sub_unit.note: Twenty-six votes for John Strong in Waterford have been added to the total for William Strong.

sub_unit.name: Chittenden
sub_unit.note: The Vermont Mirror (Middlebury, VT), January 6, 1813, reports 948 votes for Ezra Butler and 1138 votes for Jonathan H. Hubbard.

sub_unit.name: Colchester
sub_unit.note: Five votes for Jonathan Hubbard and one votes for John H. Hubbard in Colchester have been added to the total for Jonathan H. Hubbard.

sub_unit.name: Milton
sub_unit.note: One vote for Ezra Bradley in Milton has been added to the total for Ezra Butler.

sub_unit.name: Essex
sub_unit.note: The Vermont Mirror (Middlebury, VT), January 6, 1813, reports 184 votes for Ezra Butler, 185 votes for William C. Bradley, 250 votes for Chauncey Langdon and 246 votes for Jonathan H. Hubbard.

sub_unit.name: Concord
sub_unit.note: One vote for Jonathan H. Hubler in Concord has been added to the total for Jonathan H. Hubbard.
One vote for William Bradley in Concord has been added to the total for William C. Bradley.

sub_unit.name: Maidstone
sub_unit.note: One vote for Elizur Hubbard in Maidstone has been added to the total for Jonathan H. Hubbard.

sub_unit.name: Franklin
sub_unit.note: The Official Results list Richard Skinner with 1078 votes, Ezra Butler with 1078 votes and Charles Rich with 1079 votes but the town totals add up to 1079 votes for Skinner, 1079 votes for Butler and 1078 votes for Rich.
The Vermont Mirror (Middlebury, VT), January 6, 1813, reports 1078 votes for Richard Skinner, 1078 votes for Ezra Butler, 1079 votes for Charles Rich, and 1246 votes for Jonathan H. Hubbard.

sub_unit.name: Sterling
sub_unit.note: There were no votes recorded in Sterling.

sub_unit.name: Jefferson
sub_unit.note: The Vermont Mirror (Middlebury, VT), January 6, 1813, reports 866 votes for William C. Bradley.

sub_unit.name: Waterbury
sub_unit.note: One vote for William Bradley in Waterbury has been added to the total for William C. Bradley.

sub_unit.name: Orange
sub_unit.note: The Official Results list William Strong with 1804 votes and Jonathan Hubbard with 1405 votes but the town totals add up to 1800 votes for Strong and 1404 votes for Hubbard.
The Vermont Mirror (Middlebury, VT), January 6, 1813, reports 1804 votes for William Strong, 1759 votes for William C. Bradley, 1409 votes for Martin Chittenden and 1408 votes for Daniel Chipman.

sub_unit.name: Chelsea
sub_unit.note: Two votes for William Bradley in Chelsea have been added to the total for William Strong.

sub_unit.name: Newbury
sub_unit.note: One vote for William Bradley in Newbury has been added to the total for William C. Bradley.

sub_unit.name: Orange
sub_unit.note: Thirty-eight votes for William Bradley in Orange have been added to the total for William C. Bradley.

sub_unit.name: Thetford
sub_unit.note: Two votes for William Bradley in Thetford have been added to the total for William C. Bradley.

sub_unit.name: Washington
sub_unit.note: One vote for William Bradley in Washington has been added to the total for William C. Bradley.
One vote for Jonathan Hubbard in Washington has been added to the total for Jonathan H. Hubbard.
One vote for Jonathan Noyes in Washington has been added to the total for John Noyes.

sub_unit.name: Barton
sub_unit.note: Two votes for Charles Rice in Barton have been added to the total for Charles Rich.

sub_unit.name: Troy
sub_unit.note: One vote for Charles Langdon in Troy has been added to the total for Chauncey Langdon.

sub_unit.name: Rutland
sub_unit.note: The Vermont Mirror (Middlebury, VT), January 6, 1813, reports 2351 votes for Charles Rich in Rutland County.

sub_unit.name: Danby
sub_unit.note: One vote for Ezra Bradley in Danby has been added to the total for Ezra Butler.

sub_unit.name: Fairhaven
sub_unit.note: One vote for William Bradley in Fairhaven has been added to the total for William C. Bradley.
One vote for Charles Rice in Fairhaven has been added to the total for Charles Rich.
One vote for Jonathan Hubbard in Fairhaven has been added to the total for Jonathan H. Hubbard.

sub_unit.name: Poultny
sub_unit.note: One vote for William Bradley in Poultny has been added to the total for William C. Bradley.
One vote for William C. Strong in Poultny has been added to the total for William Strong.

sub_unit.name: Windham
sub_unit.note: The Vermont Mirror (Middlebury, VT), January 6, 1813, reports 2807 votes for Daniel Chipman and 2668 votes for Jonathan H. Hubbard in Windham County.

sub_unit.name: Grafton
sub_unit.note: One vote for John Hubbard in Grafton has been added to the total for Jonathan H. Hubbard.
One vote for William Bradley in Grafton has been added to the total for William C. Bradley.

sub_unit.name: Vernon
sub_unit.note: One vote for Ebenezer Chamberlain in Vernon has been added to the total for William Chamberlain.

sub_unit.note: One vote for William Hubbard in Westminster has been added to the total for Jonathan H. Hubbard.

sub_unit.name: Reading
sub_unit.note: Seven votes for William Bradley in Reading have been added to the total for William C. Bradley.
